FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE KINEMATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Chevron's El Segundo Refinery began operations in 1911 making kerosene and other products.  Since that time, the products and processes have expanded to include the making of gasoline, jet, diesel and other petroleum based products.  Over the last 50 years, the government has undertaken more and more strenuous regulations of industrial air pollution and the prevention of major releases.  As part of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990(CAA), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) was charged with overseeing the implementation of Section 112(r) of the Act.  



This section of the CAA requires industrial facilities that handle certain toxic substances or flammables to prepare a Risk Management Plan (RMP) and implement an accidental release prevention program to prevent catastrophic releases of these substances into the environment and surrounding community.  The Act also provides for public communication of this RMP to establish dialog between facilities and the surrounding community concerning the risks associated the plant.



This document presents El Segundo Refinery's RMP.  The refinery handles quantities of anhydrous ammonia, aqueous ammonia and flammable substances in amounts over the EPA threshold limits for inclusion in an RMP.  The RMP lists these chemicals, the quantities handled, and describes various scenarios whereby such substances could be released into the community.  The facility's release prevention programs are also discussed.  It should be noted that the refinery also handles other toxic substances that are not addressed in this document, even though the general refinery prevention programs do address them.  The refinery is available to discuss its hazardous substances or the contents of this document with community members at

(310) 615-5000 during business hours. During off-hours, emergency information requests or concerns should be directed to (310) 615-5342.



The Environmental Protection Agency has listed specific

lf of a mile from the facility gate. 



1.2    The Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances Handled



Toxic Substances



This RMP includes two toxic substances: anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia.



Ammonia is generated in the normal course of refining petroleum in order to remove nitrogen from the crude oil. The removal of the nitrogen with hydrogen produces ammonia. The ammonia is first collected from the process in streams of water called "sour water." The ammonia is then removed as gaseous anhydrous ammonia from the sour water by distillation. A major percentage of the cleaned water can then be re-used in the refining process, thus reducing fresh water consumption.



Flammables



The refinery contains a large amount of flammable substances subject to the RMP. These range from the smallest compounds such as methane to larger ones such as pentane. Practically any process unit in the facility contains these substances in various mixtures. Since the process units and storage vessels vary in the composition of flammables present, each was looked at separately. 



1.3    RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis



This section describes the "worst-case release" and "alternative case release" scenarios for the toxic and flammable substances at the facility.



A "worst-case release" is defined by the EPA as a release of the entire largest single-point quantity in a scenario that would create the largest offsite consequence under worst-case atmospheric conditions and a rapid release rate. The offsite consequences are determined as the distances where the released substances can reach their "endpoints."  For toxic substances the endpoints are defined as the concentrations that represent the maximums at which the agency believes that nearly all people could be exposed for up to one hour without serious or irreversible health effects.  For flammable substances, the endpoint is defined as a one pound per square inch (1 psi) overpressure caused by an explosion of the released

vapor cloud.  One psi is sufficient to break windows.  Since these worst-cases scenarios are based on extreme conditions, they are highly unlikely to occur.  Two worst-case scenarios are presented to represent the regulated toxic substances and one for regulated flammable substances handled at the refinery.  



The "alternative-case" scenarios are presented as, although still unlikely, more realistic scenarios that could occur under abnormal conditions.  One alternative release scenario is analyzed for each of the toxic substances registered in the RMP, and one alternative release scenario is presented for all flammable substances.



1.4    General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Prevention Steps

  

As discussed above, the refinery has been working with a PSM program under OSHA since the early 1990's.  The EPA recognized this OSHA process in the development of the RMP program.  The OSHA program satisfies the RMP requirements for a prevention program.  The refinery's PSM program elements include:



?    Process Safety Information

?    Process Hazards Analysis

?    Operating Procedures

?    Training

?    Mechanical Integrity

?    Management of Change

?    Pre-startup Safety Review

?    Compliance Audits

?    Incident Investigation

?    Employee Participation

?    Hot Work Permits

?    Contractors



The facility has fully implemented these elements under the OSHA standard. Additional prevention steps specific to ammonia include refinery specifications for new piping and equipment in ammonia service.  These specifications exceed most typical requirements for oil-handling equipment due to the unique hazards of ammonia.  The specifications include features such as having high reliability valves, minimal connections, using heat treated metals in vessels, selection of metals resistant to embrittlement during auto-refrigeration, and more isolation valves on liquid lines.



1.5    Five Year Accident History



There have been no incidents to report that fit the five-year criteria.





1.

6    Emergency Response Program



The refinery maintains a full-time fire department with equipment that meets the needs of responding to refinery fires and releases of chemicals, technical rescues and emergency medical situations.  An emergency response plan has been developed to address the following:



?    Specific actions to take in a response to an accidental release of hazardous chemicals;

?    Procedures for informing the public and the local agencies;

?    Information on emergency health care;

?    Information on how to communicate with the local emergency response agency;

?    Identification, maintenance, inspection and testing of emergency equipment; and

?    Training information.



This plan was developed in consultation with, and final approval by the local fire department.  The refinery fire fighters and emergency response personnel routinely drill and train to maintain their skills in emergency response.





1.7    Planned Changes to Improve Safety





The refinery continually looks for and capitalizes on opportunities to improve safety.  This section provides several examples of safety initiatives relevant to the RMP and general employee safety.

?    In 2014, the refinery fully transitioned to a new web-based ERP (Emergency Response Plan) with enhanced content and design.  This allows for easier updating of critical information for properly responding to an emergency, as well as sharing with the local fire department.

?    The refinery took delivery of a new specialized foam fire truck, and a new spill response vessel.

?    The refinery is in the process of purchasing and installing a new emergency notification and response system and a new refinery-wide radio system to prevent interference with field and console operators.

?    Much of the maintenance and capital work at the facility is performed by a contract workforce.  Due to the critical nature of their role, we are improving our contractor safety efforts through use of a process we call "Operational Excellence - Con

tractor HES Management"  This process ensures that we have and follow processes for contractor selection, training and qualification, field oversight during work, and periodic performance reviews prior to renewal of contracts.  This helps Chevron ensure that only qualified contractors with good safety records are employed in the facility and that we employ up to date training and on-boarding programs that comply with the RMP standard.

?    The refinery completed the construction of two new buildings that comply with API 751 for occupancy.  The Refinery Optimization Center (ROC) and Central Reliability Center (CRC) house our operating and support staff with required ventilation safeguards.  In the operating plants, we are constructing Field Reliability Centers (FRCs) and Blast Resistant Modules (BRMs) to house our field operators and maintenance workers.  The buildings have positive pressure ventilation, toxics analyzers for air intake, and blast resistant doors.

?    We are in the process of reviewing all existing "Legacy Instrumented Functions" (LIFs) in the refinery to verify and ensure correct documentation, asset strategies, review and update all applicable Maintenance and Operations procedures, and make minor improvements or modifications as necessary to ensure these installations will perform as designed to mitigate a PHA risk. Our central OASIS group will systematically work through each process unit over the next 10 to 13 years to upgrade or replace all "LIFs" to comply with ISA84/IEC61511 standards.  This will include the installation of additional safety functions where required".  

?    Standardized Damage Mechanism Reviews are being reviewed by our Refinery Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) teams.  The DMR work process is based on the applicable damage mechanism information outlined in API Recommended Practice 571.

1.8    Changes from Previous RMP Submittal

A handful of processes were migrated from Program 3 units to Program 1 units when it was determined they did

not meet the criteria for Program 3 (Off-Site Consequence, Accident History, Cause of injury/death, etc under 68.10(b)).  The units converted to Program 3 to Program 1 are: Iso Distillation, 4H2S, Jet Hydrofiner, 5H2S.

One process unit, the Houdries, a relief recovery system within the refinery, has been removed entirely when it was determined the one vessel that held a threshold value of flammables was actually physically located in the Naphtha Hydrotreater 3.  Those pounds have been incorporated into the quantity for that process.

Another process unit, the SNRH2BC, has also been removed due to the pounds of flammables in the process are below threshold values.  The unit used to feed butane, but the butane feed system has been decommissioned and the flammable pounds feel below the threshold quantity.

An update of the process Ammonia Product System inventory was made after discovery that only the pounds of ammonia were reported despite it being a solution of ammonia with water.  This also impacted our WCS for Aqueous Ammonia, with a vessel taking the place of our previous WCS of a railcar failure.
